datasource: Almkvist1881; section references abbreviated in :note as AL# [The verbal paradigms are mostly taken from the sections V. and VI, pp. 162-238, #231-326; the stemClass values have been chosen in such a way as to provide maximum isomorphism with the sequence of the paradigms in AlmkvistZZs grammar if the AAMA-application Source Table columns are arranged in the order: Source Pos Conjclass Rootclass Stemclass Lexeme Derivedstem Polarity Tam]
datasourceNotes: In order to avoid confusion and for ease of comparison,  what Almkvist calls ZZAoristZZ is here termed ZZFutureZZ. AlmkvistZZs informants were apparently unaware of the second past tense frequently termed ZZAoristZZ in the other varieties of Beja currently recorded in AAMA (cf. Appleyard2007, p. 468). Note that Alm has Person3 negative imperatives which seem distinct from optatives (and jussives?). Note also that Almkvist calls both the T-stem and the M stem ZZPassiveZZ, and  that a SM seems to exist.
geodemoTXT: Beja is a closely related group of language varieties and dialects spoken in the Red Sea coastal and hill regions in Sudan, Eritrea, and Egypt by more than a million individuals. The Northern-most representative of Beja is documented here, that of the Bishari in Aswan and Sudan, studied by Herman Almkvist (1881) in one of the earliest monographs dedicated to a variety of Beja.
